name: hub-manual
description: Agent Hub system documentation and best practices

entries.content: Agent Hub is a framework for building multi-agent AI systems. It consists of agencies (containers for agents), blueprints (agent templates), and plugins (capability extensions). Each agency can have multiple agents running concurrently.

A blueprint defines an agent type with: name (identifier), description (what it does), prompt (system instructions), capabilities (list of plugins/tools), and optional model override. Blueprints starting with _ are system blueprints and hidden from users.

Capabilities in a blueprint can be: plugin names (e.g., 'planning', 'memory'), tool names (e.g., 'internet_search'), or tags with @ prefix (e.g., '@default' includes all default tools). Multiple capabilities can be combined.
The planning plugin adds todo list management. Agents can create, update, and complete tasks. Best used for complex multi-step operations. Add 'planning' to capabilities to enable.

The memory plugin provides semantic search over .idz memory files. It requires EMBEDDING_API_BASE and EMBEDDING_API_KEY vars. Agents can recall (search) and remember (store) information. Add 'memory' to capabilities.
The filesystem plugin provides read/write access to the agency's R2-backed storage. Agents have a home directory (~/) and shared space (/shared/). Add 'filesystem' to capabilities.
The subagents plugin allows agents to spawn child agents for subtasks. Children report back to parents when done. Useful for parallel work or specialized tasks. Add 'subagents' to capabilities.
The hitl (human-in-the-loop) plugin pauses execution for certain tool calls, requiring user approval. Useful for sensitive operations. Add 'hitl' to capabilities and configure HITL_TOOLS var.

Agency variables (vars) are key-value configuration accessible to all agents. Common vars: LLM_API_KEY, LLM_API_BASE, EMBEDDING_API_KEY, EMBEDDING_API_BASE, DEFAULT_MODEL. Set via Agency settings or API.
Schedules allow automatic agent spawning. Types: 'once' (single run at time), 'cron' (recurring pattern), 'interval' (every N milliseconds). Schedules can be paused, resumed, or manually triggered.
The Agency Mind (_agency-mind) is a special agent that manages its parent agency. It can list/create/update blueprints, manage agents, view schedules, and configure variables. Each agency has one.
The Hub Mind (_hub-mind) is the top-level intelligence managing all agencies. It lives in the _system agency and can create/delete agencies, get hub-wide statistics, and provide guidance.
Best practice for blueprint prompts: Be specific about the agent's role, list what it should and shouldn't do, mention available tools, and set expectations for output format.
Best practice for capabilities: Start minimal and add as needed. '@default' gives common tools. Add 'planning' for complex tasks. Add 'memory' if the agent needs to remember across sessions.
Memory disks are .idz files in /shared/memories/. They store entries with semantic embeddings for search. Create topic-specific disks like 'user-preferences', 'project-notes', 'learned-facts'.

To create a good agent: 1) Define clear purpose in description, 2) Write detailed system prompt, 3) Choose minimal necessary capabilities, 4) Test with sample conversations, 5) Iterate on prompt based on results.
